subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Quickscript Unicode Proposal
msgSnippet: ... Yes, one of the principles behind Unicode is that only distinct characters should be encoded if possible, and alternates (like ligatures) should be handled
messageBody:
On Apr 12, 2006, at 4:28 PM, Paige Gabhart wrote:

> Your suggestion regarding avoiding separate glyphs for diphthongs (as
> opposed to the encoding in Shavian) also seems sensible to me from my
> position of Unicode ignorance. Does this imply that joined diphthong
> letters could still be displayed?

Yes, one of the principles behind Unicode is that only distinct
characters should be encoded if possible, and alternates (like
ligatures) should be handled by software. If the software supports it,
systems like OpenType allow for easy automatic substitution. In this
way, you would type something like <ar>, and it would be stored as such
(which is useful for sorting, searching, and other processing tasks),
but could be automatically displayed as <x> for ease of reading.

> I would like to suggest the use of an alternate glyph for the letter
> "Ye," which would be the half-letter "Ye", i.e. the top of the
> standard letter. In the long years since I started using QS, at some
> point, I extended Read's logic behind half-letters and devised that
> half-letter myself, albeit, inadvertently. It works just as well as a
> half-"T" or half-"P" does and causes no confusion in reading. When I
> began using it, I was quite familiar with QS and had not found it
> necessary to review the manual on any regular basis then.
> Consequently, I did not realize it was an addition to the alphabet
> until it was pointed it out to me. If we are going to have
> half-letters available, which I feel add much interest to the alphabet
> as well as producing more distinctive and easily recognizable
> word-shapes, there really seems no reason not to include it as an
> alternate glyph along with the other half-letters.

I can agree with this as an option. In fact, I sometimes use a Half-Ye
myself. The procedure would be as described above: You would type the
full letters and enable half letters for automatic replacement.
The greatest benefit of this approach, I think, is the ability to store
both Junior and Senior Quikscript with the same encoding and display
the same text in either form. If I'm a little out of practice (and I
am), I may turn off connected letters and read Junior just until I'm
comfortable connecting them again.

All of this, of course, depends on software being able to support these
advanced features. Most doesn't. As far as I know, all new Adobe
software supports OpenType, and some others (some Microsoft products
for example) have limited support. Other similar systems exist that
could do the same thing, but none are as popular and as likely to catch
on.

Regards,
Joseph Spicer
